title: Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for Inhalation Injury
description: Classifies inhalation injury severity based on bronchoscopic findings in adult patients with suspected inhalation injury undergoing flexible bronchoscopy

parameters.name: bronchoscopic_findings
parameters.description: Bronchoscopic findings observed during flexible bronchoscopy

result.name: ais_score
result.description: AIS score for inhalation injury severity

ranges.interpretation: No carbonaceous deposits, erythema, edema, bronchorrhea, or obstruction. Normal bronchoscopic findings.
Minor or patchy areas of erythema, carbonaceous deposits, bronchorrhea, or bronchial obstruction present. Minimal inhalation injury with generally good prognosis.
Moderate erythema, carbonaceous deposits, bronchorrhea, or bronchial obstruction present. Moderate inhalation injury requiring close monitoring and supportive care.

Severe inflammation with friability, copious carbonaceous deposits, bronchorrhea, or obstruction present. Severe inhalation injury with increased risk of ARDS, prolonged mechanical ventilation, and ICU stay.
Mucosal sloughing, necrosis, or endoluminal obstruction present. Very severe inhalation injury with high morbidity and mortality risk requiring intensive support and possible referral to burn center.

references: Endorf FW, Gamelli RL. Inhalation injury, pulmonary perturbations, and fluid resuscitation. J Burn Care Res. 2007;28(1):80-83.
Albright JM, Davis CS, Bird MD, et al. The acute pulmonary inflammatory response to the graded severity of smoke inhalation injury. Crit Care Med. 2012;40(4):1113-1121.
Mosier MJ, Pham TN, Park DR, et al. Predictive value of bronchoscopy in assessing the severity of inhalation injury. J Burn Care Res. 2012;33(1):65-73.
formula: AIS Score = Grade based on bronchoscopic findings (0-4 scale)
notes: The AIS may predict development of ARDS, length of mechanical ventilation, and prolonged ICU stay
AIS severity has not been consistently associated with mortality
High AIS severity alone should not dictate management decisions
Bronchoscopic findings cannot reliably reflect overall severity of airway inhalation injury
Macroscopic manifestations of airway abnormalities may be delayed
Consider referring patients to designated burn centers for any inhalation injury
